facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 340 of 1958 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 340 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal against Judgment and Order dated July 3, 1953 of Punjab High Court in Civil Writ Application No. 256 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated July 3, 1953, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Writ Application No. 256 of 1952.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 21, 1961 by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed petition under Art. 226 seeking to quash orders of Custodian General dated June 17, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is against the order of the Punjab High Court dismissing the petition of the appellants under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for quashing the orders of the Custodian General, dated June 17, 1952.

facts.text: Appellants and respondents Nos. 4 and 5 are residents of village Baland, Tehsil and District Rohtak, members of body of proprietors.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants and respondents Nos. 4 and 5 are, residents of village Baland, Tehsil and District Rohtak, and are members of the body of proprietors of that village.

facts.text: Village Baland divided between three estates; plot in suit in estate known as Barsan.

anchor.surface_text: The village Baland is divided between three estates. The plot in suit is in the estate known as Barsan.

facts.text: Fakira, a mendicant and number-proprietor, had his house on the plot in suit.

anchor.surface_text: One Fakira, a mendicant and a number-proprietor, had his house on the plot in suit.

facts.text: In January 1950, Custodian of Evacuee Property issued notice under s.7 of Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949 to appellants for unauthorised possession of Fakira's house, a Muslim evacuee.

anchor.surface_text: In January, 1950, the Custodian of Evacuee Property issued a numberice under s. 7 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949, stating that the appellants were in unauthorised possession of the house of Fakira, a Muslim evacuee,

facts.text: Appellants filed objections to the notice.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed their objections to the numberice.

facts.text: Deputy Custodian order dated September 3, 1950 rejected objections and declared house evacuee property after enquiry by Revenue Assistant Rehabilitation.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Custodian of Evacuee Property, by his order dated September 3, 1950, rejected the objections raised by the appellants and declared the house to be evacuee property. The Deputy Custodian passed this order after he got an enquiry made through the Revenue Assistant Rehabilitation.

facts.text: Appellants appealed to Additional Custodian, Evacuee Property.

anchor.surface_text: The appel- lants went in appeal to the Additional Custodian, Evacuee Property,

facts.text: Additional Custodian enquired if Mumtaz, son of Fakira, in occupation up to migration; revealed Mumtaz resided in Baland, son born July 1947.

anchor.surface_text: who got further enquiry made to ascertain whether Mumtaz, son of Fakira, evacuee, had been in occupation of the house up to the date of the migration of the Muslims as a result of the partition. This enquiry revealed that Mumtaz had companytinued to reside in the village Baland and that a son was born to him in July, 1947.

facts.text: Additional Custodian agreed with Deputy Custodian that property is evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Custodian therefore agreed with the report and the order of the Deputy Custodian that the property in suit was evacuee property.

facts.text: Custodian General dismissed revision on June 17, 1952; evidence Mumtaz in possession up to July 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then filed a revision before the Custodian General. It was dismissed on June 17, 1952. The Custodian General observed that there was more than sufficient evidence to establish that Mumtaz companytinued to be in possession of the house in dispute up to July, 1947.

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petition challenging Deputy Custodian order on grounds of no notice/opportunity and no jurisdiction due to wajib-ul-arz.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellants filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging the legality of the order of the Deputy Custodian on the grounds that the Deputy Custodian gave numbernotice or opportunity to them to meet the case and that the Custodian had numberjurisdiction in the matter in view of the provisions of the wajibul-arz according to which the house of a number-proprietor, on his leaving the village, vested in the proprietory body.

facts.text: Single Judge held provisions of Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 complied with; referred question to larger Bench.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge who heard the petition held that the provisions of the Administration of the Evacuee Property Act, 1950  Act XXXI of 1950 , had been companyplied with throughout and referred the question whether the site occupied by a number-proprietor vested or number in the Custodian after the occupier had abandoned it,

facts.text: Division Bench held right of number-proprietor to occupy village site is right in property vesting in Custodian if evacuee.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench then decided this question and held the right of a number- proprietor to occupy a village site was a right in property, though it might number be an interest in property and that this right vested in the Custodian if the number-proprietor left the companyntry and became an evacuee.

facts.text: Appellants case: Fakira had no right vesting in Custodian due to wajib-ul-arz and being licensee.

anchor.surface_text: The case for the appellants is that Fakira had numbersuch right which companyld vest in the Custodian both on account of the terms of the wajib-ul-arz and on account of his being a licensee.

facts.text: Fakira resided in the house; occupied site and built house with permission; number-proprietor per wajib-ul-arz.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that Fakira who resided in the house in suit, was number a tenant of it. He occupied the site and probably built the house himself on getting the necessary permission from the proprietors. With respect to number-proprietors, the wajib-ul-arz of the village states

facts.text: Fakira and son Mumtaz migrated to Pakistan at partition; abandoned village.

anchor.surface_text: Fakira abandoned the house only in 1947 at the time of partition. The entire case was that Fakira had migrated to Pakistan and had abandoned the village.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Fakira not a tenant; s.18 not applicable; rights per wajib-ul-arz extinguished on abandonment; property not evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that Fakira did number possess any such right in the land in suit which companyld vest in the Custodian and that therefore the property in suit is number evacuee property.

This appeal, by special leave, is against the order of the Punjab High Court dismissing the petition of the appellants under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for quashing the orders of the Custodian General, dated June 17, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: With respect to number-proprietors, the wajib-ul-arz of the village states No number-proprietor can settle in the village or build a house without the consent of the owner of the estate. Whenever anybody settles, he obtains land or house from the proprietor of the same and he can live there so long as he pleases.

anchor.surface_text: Joti Parshad v. Bhawani Lal required re-consideration. The Division Bench then decided this question and held the right of a number- proprietor to occupy a village site was a right in property, though it might not be an interest in property and that this right vested in the Custodian if the number-proprietor left the country and became an evacuee.

precedents.citation: Associated Hotels of India v. R. N. Kapoor  1

anchor.surface_text: Associated Hotels of India v. R. N. Kapoor  1  for supporting the contention that Fakira was a lessee of the land in suit and number a licensee. We do number think this case supports the contention. The following propositions were laid down in that case for determining whether a document creates a licence or a lease To ascertain whether a document creates a licence or lease, the substance of the document must be preferred to the form.

precedents.case_name: Associated Hotels of India v R N Kapoor
precedents.cited_proposition: propositions for determining whether a document creates a licence or a lease
precedents.cited_holding: To ascertain whether a document creates a licence or lease, the substance of the document must be preferred to the form. The real test is the intention of the parties whether they intended to create a lease or a licence. If the document creates an interest in the property, it is a lease, but, if it only permits another to make use of the property, of which the legal possession continues with the owner, it is a licence, and If under the document a party gets exclusive possession of the property, prima facie, he is considered to be a tenant, but circumstances may be established which negative that intention to create a lease.
